sentence: Trade is as old as humanity, or nearly so.

sentence: Today, in a world of container ships, jumbo jets, and the Internet, goods and many services are delivered faster and more cheaply (in inflation-adjusted terms) than ever before.1 Today I will discuss the crucial economic benefits we receive from the ongoing expansion of international trade.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the economic benefits of international trade and does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: I will also address the adverse effects of trade and some possible ways to mitigate them.
reason: This sentence suggests that the speaker will discuss the negative impacts of trade and potential measures to alleviate them. While it does not directly indicate a stance on US monetary policy, it is irrelevant to determining whether the policy will be hawkish, dovish, or neutral.

sentence: I will argue that one possible response to the dislocations that may result from trade--a retreat into protectionism and isolationism--would be self-defeating and, in the long run, probably not even feasible.
reason: This sentence suggests a dovish stance on US monetary policy. It implies that a retreat into protectionism and isolationism, as a response to trade dislocations, would be self-defeating and not feasible in the long run. This implies a preference for a more open and global approach, which aligns with a dovish stance.

sentence: Instead, our continued prosperity depends on our embracing the many opportunities provided by trade, even as we provide a helping hand to individuals and communities that may have suffered adverse consequences.

sentence: The Benefits of TradeAt the most basic level, trade is beneficial because it allows people to specialize in the goods and services they produce best and most efficiently.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the benefits of trade, which is not directly related to the decision-making process of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) in determining interest rates.

sentence: For example, we could conceivably all grow our own food and provide our own medical care.

sentence: But because farming and medicine require special knowledge and skills, a far more efficient arrangement is for the farmer to specialize in growing food and for the doctor to specialize in treating patients.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the efficiency of specialization in farming and medicine. It does not provide any implications or insights related to the monetary policy stance, making it unrelated to the terms hawkish, dovish, neutral.

sentence: Through the specialization made possible by trade, the farmer can benefit from the doctor's medical knowledge and the doctor can enjoy lunch.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the benefits of trade and specialization between a farmer and a doctor, without any direct implications on the monetary policy stance.

sentence: The opportunity to trade allows everyone to play to his or her own strengths while benefiting from the productive skills of the whole community.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the opportunity to trade and the benefits of productive skills within a community, without any direct implications on the monetary policy stance.

sentence: Indeed, economists have demonstrated that trade between two people can be beneficial even if one of them is more skilled than the other at every task, so long as the more-skilled person specializes in those tasks at which he or she is relatively more productive.What applies to individuals applies to nations as well.

sentence: Two centuries ago the economist David Ricardo famously observed that, if England specialized in making cloth while Portugal specialized in producing wine, international trade would allow both countries to enjoy more of both goods than would be possible if each country produced only for domestic consumption and did not trade.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the concept of international trade and specialization, which does not directly impact the stance of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) on interest rates or other monetary policy tools.

sentence: As in the case of individuals, this conclusion applies even if one country can produce both cloth and wine more cheaply than the other, so long as each country specializes in the activity at which it is relatively more productive.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses comparative advantage in international trade rather than addressing any specific stance on interest rates or monetary measures.

sentence: A telling confirmation of Ricardo's insight is that, when nations go to war, their first order of business is often to try to block the other's access to trade.

reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the trade surplus in services, which does not directly impact the stance of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) regarding interest rates or other monetary policy tools.

sentence: This country provides many high-value services to users abroad, including financial, legal, engineering, architectural, and software development services, whereas many of the services imported by U.S. companies are less sophisticated and hence of lower value.9 A recent study of twenty-one occupations that are most likely to be affected by outsourcing found that net job losses were concentrated almost exclusively in the lower-wage occupations and that strong employment gains have occurred in the occupations that pay the highest wages.10 Further expansion of trade in services will help, not hurt, the U.S. economy and the labor market.Just as discussions of the outsourcing of business services tend to ignore the services U.S. firms sell to other countries, so do discussions of the movement of jobs offshore ignore the fact that foreign firms also move jobs to the United States.

sentence: Globalization and offshoring work both ways.Responding to Job DisplacementAlthough trade has many positive effects in the labor market, nothing I have said this morning is intended to minimize the real costs imposed on workers and communities when new competition from abroad leads to job losses and displacement.

sentence: What can be done to help workers who lose their jobs as a consequence of expanded trade?
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it focuses on the impact of expanded trade on workers who lose their jobs. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: Restricting trade by imposing tariffs, quotas, or other barriers is exactly the wrong thing to do.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses trade restrictions rather than monetary measures. It does not provide any implications on whether the policy stance would be hawkish, dovish, or neutral.

sentence: Such solutions might temporarily slow job loss in affected industries, but the benefits would be outweighed, typically many times over, by the costs, which would include higher prices for consumers and increased costs (and thus reduced competitiveness) for U.S. firms.
reason: This sentence suggests a hawkish stance on US monetary policy. It implies that implementing certain solutions to slow job loss in affected industries may have negative consequences, such as higher prices for consumers and reduced competitiveness for US firms.

sentence: In the long run, economic isolationism and retreat from international competition would inexorably lead to lower productivity for U.S. firms and lower living standards for U.S. consumers (Bernanke, 2004).The better approach to mitigating the disruptive effects of trade is to adopt policies and programs aimed at easing the transition of displaced workers into new jobs and increasing the adaptability and skills of the labor force more generally.
reason: This sentence from the FOMC is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it focuses on the long-term implications of economic isolationism and the importance of adopting policies to mitigate the effects of trade. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: Currently, the government's principal program for helping workers displaced by trade is the Trade Adjustment Assistance program, which is up for renewal before the Congress this year.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the government's program for helping workers displaced by trade, which does not directly impact the monetary policy stance.

sentence: As now structured, the program offers up to two and a half years of job training, allowances for job search and relocation, income support for eligible workers, and health insurance assistance for some.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses a program related to job training, job search, relocation, income support, and health insurance assistance for workers. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: Elements of other proposals being discussed (Kletzer and Rosen, 2006; Kling, 2006; Mann 2003, 2004) include job-training tax credits and wage insurance, which would help offset pay cuts that often occur when displaced workers change jobs.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses job-training tax credits and wage insurance, which are not directly related to the hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) on interest rates and monetary policy.

sentence: Another approach is to focus on establishing policies that reduce the cost to workers of changing jobs, for example, by increasing the portability of pensions or health insurance between employers.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses policies related to reducing the cost to workers of changing jobs, such as increasing the portability of pensions or health insurance between employers. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: However, I can safely predict that these and other policy proposals to address concerns about worker displacement will be the subject of active debate in coming years.More generally, investing in education and training would help young people entering the labor force as well as those already in mid-career to better manage the ever-changing demands of the workforce (Bernanke, 2007).

sentence: Importantly, workforce skills can be improved not only through Kâ12 education, college, and graduate work but also through a variety of expeditious, market-based channels such as on-the-job training, coursework at community colleges and vocational schools, extension courses, and online training.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses workforce skills and education, which are not directly related to the monetary policy stance.

sentence: An eclectic, market-responsive approach to increasing workforce skills is the most likely to be successful.Whatever the specific approaches chosen, helping workers who have lost jobs--whether because of trade or other causes--to find new productive work is good for the economy as well as for the affected workers and their families.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it focuses on workforce skills and job displacement rather than monetary policy. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: Moreover, if workers and their families are less fearful of change, political pressure in favor of trade barriers or other measures that would reduce the flexibility and dynamism of the U.S. economy would be reduced (Kull, 2004).ConclusionTo sum up, international trade in goods, services, and assets, like other forms of market-based exchange, allows us to transform what we have into what we need or want under increasingly beneficial terms.

sentence: Some features of the world trading regime, such as excessive restrictions on trade in services and the uneven protection of intellectual property rights, are both unfair and economically counterproductive.
